oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Malignant catarrhal fever: [Symposium: Clinical Aspects of Bovine Viral Diseases]
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mebus, C. A.
Kalunda, M.
Ferris, D. H.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Diagnosis
mucosal disease
Reviews
Symptoms
arboviruses
Symposium: Clinical Aspects of Bovine Viral Diseases
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Malignant catarrhal fever (MCF) is a disease of cattle, buffalo, American bison, and deer caused by a herpesvirus. The disease can occur in one or in a combination of 4 forms - peracute, head and eye, intestinal and mild. The most commonly recognized natural disease is the head and eye form. Generally MCF has a low morbidity and high mortality.
